Description: Samsung Electronics Company Ltd., a Korean manufacturer of dynamic random access memory (DRAM), and its U.S. subsidiary Samsung Semiconductor Inc. agreed to plead guilty and to pay a $300 million fine for participating in an international conspiracy to fix prices in the DRAM market.

Samsung Electronics America Inc. agreed to pay $2.3 million to resolve allegations that it caused the submission of false claims for products sold on General Service Administration Multiple Award Schedule contracts in violation of the Trade Agreements Act of 1979.

Description: Samsung SDI Company Ltd. agreed to plead guilty and to pay a $32 million criminal fine for its role in a global conspiracy to fix prices, reduce output and allocate market shares of color display tubes (CDTs), a type of cathode ray tube used in computer monitors and other specialized applications.

Description: The California Attorney General announced settlements resolving allegations that LG, Hitachi, Panasonic, Toshiba, and Samsung, companies all based in Japan or Korea, fixed prices on cathode ray tubes from 1995 to 2007.
The Washington Attorney General announced that Samsung agreed to pay $29 million as part of the AG's price-fixing lawsuit against seven manufacturers of cathode ray tubes, or CRTs, from 1995 to 2007.

Attorney General Bob Ferguson announced settlements totaling $44 million from seven liquid crystal display (LCD) manufacturers accused of engaging in a price-fixing conspiracy that drove up prices consumers paid on items like TVs, laptops and cell phones.
Seven manufacturers of flat screen LCD (Liquid Crystal Display) panels agreed to pay more than $500 million to settle multistate price-fixing allegations.

Company: Samsung Semiconductor, Inc. and Samsung Electronics Company, Ltd.
Description: Samsung Semiconductor and Samsung Electronics agreed to pay $90 million to resolve multistate allegations that it and other major computer chip manufacturers fixed prices of Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM).

LG Electronics, Panasonic, Samsung, Sharp and Sony agreed to pay a total of $1.25 million and contribute $1.125 million of audio-visual equipment to Californian schools and institutions in settlement of allegations by District Attorneys in seven counties that they violated state law by stating TV screen sizes rounded to the nearest inch. The announcement did not specify how much each company would pay. Here we assume the amounts were divided equally among the five.
